text: Consumer Banking added ~278,000 net new checking accounts, marking 22 consecutive quarters of growth.
Consumer Banking added ~1MM credit card accounts.
Consumer Banking reported record consumer investment assets of $476B, up 23% YoY, with 3.9MM accounts, up 6%.
Consumer Banking saw 13 consecutive quarters of Small Business loan growth.
Global Wealth & Investment Management added ~6,100 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank.
Global Wealth & Investment Management opened ~30,000 new bank accounts, with over 60% of clients having a banking relationship.
Global Wealth & Investment Management reported record client balances of over $4T, up 10% YoY.
Global Wealth & Investment Management grew loan balances 3% YoY to $225B.
Global Banking ranked #3 in investment banking fees and grew 1H24 market share by 42 bps YoY.
Global Banking grew 1H24 investment banking fees 32% YoY to $3.1B.
Global Banking grew Middle Market loan balances 4% YoY.
Global Banking grew average deposits 6% from 2Q23.
Global Markets has had 9 consecutive quarters of YoY sales and trading revenue growth.
Global Markets reported the highest 2Q sales and trading revenue in over a decade.
Global Markets saw record average loan balances of $135B, up 5% YoY, marking 15 consecutive quarters of growth.
Global Markets had zero trading loss days in 1H24.
Total deposits, loans, and investment balances reached $5.7T.
Total net wealth spectrum flows were $58B since 2Q23.
Net income was $6.9B, with diluted earnings per share of $0.83, ROE of 10.0%, and ROTCE of 13.6%.

Revenue, net of interest expense, increased by $0.2B (1%) to $25.4B, reflecting higher asset management, investment banking fees, and sales and trading revenue, offset by lower net interest income (NII).
NII of $13.7B ($13.9B FTE) decreased $0.5B, or 3%, as higher deposit costs more than offset higher asset yields and modest loan growth.
Provision for credit losses was $1.5B, compared to $1.1B in 2Q23 and $1.3B in 1Q24.
Net charge-offs of $1.5B increased from 2Q23, driven by credit card and commercial real estate office, but were relatively flat compared to 1Q24.
There was a net reserve release of $25MM, versus a net reserve build of $256MM in 2Q23 and a net reserve release of $179MM in 1Q24.
Noninterest expense of $16.3B increased $0.3B, or 2%, driven by investments in people and revenue-related compensation.
The balance sheet remained strong, with average deposits of $1.91T increasing by $35B (2%) vs. 2Q23.
Average loans and leases of $1.05T increased modestly vs. 2Q23.
Average Global Liquidity Sources were $909B.
Common Equity Tier 1 capital of $198B increased $1B from 1Q24.
Returned $5.4B to shareholders, including $1.9B in common dividends and $3.5B in stock repurchases.
Announced an 8% increase in quarterly common dividend, effective 3Q24.
Common Equity Tier 1 ratio of 11.9% increased 6 bps from 1Q24, standing 122 bps above the new regulatory minimum effective October 1, 2024.
CET1 ratio of 11.9% increased 6 bps from 1Q24.
CET1 capital of $198B increased $1B.
Standardized RWA of $1,662B increased $4B.
Book value per share of $34.39 improved 7% from 2Q23; tangible book value per share of $25.37 improved 9% from 2Q23.
Average Global Liquidity Sources of $909B were flat compared to 1Q24.
Net interest income for 2Q24 was $13.7B ($13.9B FTE).
NII decreased $0.5B YoY due to higher deposit costs offsetting higher asset yields, higher NII from Global Markets, and modest loan growth.
NII decreased $0.3B from 1Q24, primarily driven by higher deposit costs.
NII related to Global Markets activity increased by approximately $0.5B YoY and $0.1B from 1Q24.
Net interest yield of 1.93% decreased 13 bps YoY and 6 bps from 1Q24.
Excluding Global Markets, the net interest yield was 2.41%.
1Q24 and 4Q23 noninterest expense of $17.2B and $17.7B included accruals of $0.7B and $2.1B respectively, for the FDIC special assessment.
2Q24 noninterest expense of $16.3B increased $0.3B (2%) vs. 2Q23, driven by investments in people and revenue-related compensation, partially offset by lower litigation expense.

Noninterest expense declined $0.9B (5%) vs. 1Q24, due to the absence of the FDIC special assessment accrual and seasonally higher payroll taxes in the first quarter, partially offset by higher revenue-related expenses.
Total net charge-offs of $1.5B increased by $35MM from 1Q24.
Consumer net charge-offs of $1.1B increased by $31MM, driven by higher credit card losses.
Credit card loss rate was 3.88% in 2Q24, up from 3.62% in 1Q24.
Commercial net charge-offs of $474MM were relatively flat.
The net charge-off ratio of 0.59% increased 1 bp from 1Q24.
Provision for credit losses of $1.5B increased by $189MM vs. 1Q24.
There was a net reserve release of $25MM in 2Q24 vs. $179MM in 1Q24.
Allowance for loan and lease losses of $13.2B represented 1.26% of total loans and leases.
Total allowance of $14.3B included $1.1B for unfunded commitments.
Nonperforming loans (NPLs) of $5.5B decreased by $0.4B from 1Q24, driven primarily by the commercial real estate office portfolio.
61% of Consumer NPLs are contractually current.
Commercial reservable criticized utilized exposure of $24.8B increased by $0.2B from 1Q24.
Net income was $2.6B.
Revenue of $10.2B decreased 3% from 2Q23, primarily due to lower deposit balances.
Provision for credit losses of $1.3B was relatively flat compared to 2Q23.
Net charge-offs of $1.2B increased by $369MM from 2Q23, driven by credit card.
Net reserve build was $93MM vs. $448MM in 2Q23.
Noninterest expense of $5.5B was relatively flat compared to 2Q23, with an efficiency ratio of 54%.
Average deposits of $949B decreased $57B, or 6%, from 2Q23.
58% of deposits are in checking accounts, and 92% are primary accounts.
Average loans and leases of $312B increased $6B, or 2%, from 2Q23.
Combined credit/debit card spend of $234B increased 3% from 2Q23.
Record consumer investment assets of $476B grew $89B, or 23%, from 2Q23, driven by $38B of net client flows.
There are 3.9MM consumer investment accounts, up 6%.
11.1MM total clients are enrolled in Preferred Rewards, up 7% from 2Q23, with a 99% annualized retention rate.
Net income was $1.0B.
Revenue of $5.6B increased 6% from 2Q23, driven by 14% higher asset management fees, due to higher market levels and strong AUM flows, partially offset by lower net interest income.
Noninterest expense of $4.2B increased 7% vs. 2Q23, driven by revenue-related incentives.
Client balances of $4T increased 10% from 2Q23, driven by higher market valuations and positive net client flows, including AUM flows of $11B in 2Q24.
Average deposits of $288B decreased $8B, or 3%, from 2Q23.
Average loans and leases of $223B increased $4B, or 2%, from 2Q23.
Added ~6,100 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank in 2Q24.
85% of GWIM households/relationships are digitally active across the enterprise, up from 83% in 2Q23.
Net income was $2.1B.
Revenue of $6.1B decreased 6% from 2Q23, driven primarily by lower net interest income and leasing revenue, partially offset by higher investment banking fees.
Total Corporation investment banking fees (ex. self-led) of $1.6B increased 29% vs. 2Q23, achieving a #3 investment banking fee ranking.
Provision for credit losses was $235MM vs. $9MM in 2Q23.
Net charge-offs of $346MM increased $287MM from 2Q23, driven primarily by commercial real estate office.
There was a net reserve release of $111MM vs. a $50MM build in 2Q23.
Noninterest expense of $2.9B increased 3% vs. 2Q23.
Average deposits of $525B increased $28B, or 6%, from 2Q23.
Average loans and leases of $373B decreased $10B, or 3%, from 2Q23, reflecting lower client demand.
Net income was $1.4B, both including and excluding net DVA.
Revenue of $5.5B increased 12% from 2Q23, driven by higher sales and trading revenue and investment banking fees.
Sales and trading revenue of $4.7B increased 9% from 2Q23; excluding net DVA, it was up 7%.
FICC revenue increased 3% (ex. DVA, down 1%) to $2.7B, driven by improved client activity in mortgages, partially offset by weaker trading in foreign exchange and interest rates.
Equities revenue increased 20% (ex. DVA, up 20%) to $1.9B, driven by strong client activity in cash and derivatives.
Noninterest expense of $3.5B increased 4% vs. 2Q23, driven by higher revenue-related expenses and investments in the business, including technology.
Average VaR was $90MM in 2Q24.
The 'All Other' segment primarily consists of asset and liability management (ALM) activities, liquidating businesses, and certain unallocated corporate expenses.
Reported a net loss of $0.3B.
The result improved by $0.4B vs. 1Q24, primarily due to the absence of the $0.7B accrual for the FDIC special assessment that was recorded in the previous quarter.
The total corporate effective tax rate (ETR) for the quarter was approximately 9%.
Excluding discrete tax items and recurring tax credits (primarily related to renewable energy and affordable housing), the ETR would have been approximately 25%.
Office properties comprise ~75% Class A property type, ~55% origination LTV, and have ~11% NPL to loans.
NPLs for office properties are down $0.3B vs. 1Q24.
$5.1B reservable criticized exposure for office is down $0.5B vs. 1Q24, with ~80% LTV.
2Q24 NCOs for office were $0.2B, down $0.1B vs. 1Q24.
Bank of America is ranked #1 in U.S. Retail Deposit Market Share.
Deposits in excess of loans grew from $0.5T in 4Q19, peaked at $1.1T in 4Q21, and remained elevated at $0.9T in 2Q24.
Excess deposits are stored in cash and investment securities, with 52% in cash and AFS and 48% in HTM in 2Q24.
Cash levels of $321B remain well above the pre-pandemic level of $162B in 4Q19.
AFS securities are mostly hedged with floating rate swaps, have a duration of less than 0.5 years, and are marked through AOCI and regulatory capital.
The HTM securities book has declined by $106B since peaking at $683B in 3Q21, down $37B vs. 2Q23 and $9B vs. 1Q24.
The blended cash and securities yield continued to improve in 2Q24 and is 160 bps above the deposit rate paid.
No. 1 in estimated U.S. Retail Deposits.
No. 1 Small Business Lender.
Named Best Bank in North America and Best Bank in the U.S.
Recognized as Best Consumer Digital Bank in the U.S., with the Best Integrated Consumer Banking Site & Best Mobile Banking App.
Named Best Bank in the U.S. for Small and Medium Enterprises.
Certified by J.D. Power for Outstanding Client Satisfaction with Customer Financial Health Support â€“ Banking & Payments.
Recognized as No. 1 on Forbes' Best-in-State Wealth Advisors (2023), Top Women Wealth Advisors (2024), and Top Next Generation Advisors (2023).
No. 1 on Barron's Top 1200 Wealth Financial Advisors List (2024).
No. 1 on Financial Planning's 'Top 40 Advisors Under 40' List (2024).
Ranked No. 1 in personal trust AUM.
Named Best Private Bank (U.S.), Best Private Bank for Philanthropic Services and Sustainable Investing (North America).
Named Best Private Bank in the Nation, Best Private Bank for Family Office and OCIO.
Named Best Private Bank (U.S.), Best Private Bank for Digital Innovation, Best Family Office Offering, and Excellence in Philanthropy Services.
Recognized as World's Most Innovative Bank - 2024.
Named World's Best Digital Bank, World's Best Bank for Financing, and other awards.
2023 Best Bank for Cash & Liquidity Management and other related awards.
Named Best Global Bank for Transaction Banking and Best Global Bank for Collections.
Received Model Bank Award for Reimagining Trade & Supply Chain Finance in 2024.
Received 2023 Share & Excellence Awards for U.S. Large Corporate Banking & Cash Management.
Maintains relationships with 74% of the Global Fortune 500 and 95% of the U.S. Fortune 1,000.
Recognized with multiple business leadership awards including Securitization Bank of the Year, CLO Trading Desk of the Year, and Derivatives House of the Year.
Also named Base Metals House of the Year and Currency Derivatives House of the Year.
Lead Manager of the Year for social, green, and sustainability bonds.
Ranked No. 1 Foreign Exchange Options Market Dealer.
Recognized as Best CLO Tranche Trading Desk and Best Research House.

Note A explains the 1Q24 non-GAAP adjustments for the FDIC special assessment (FDIC SA) of $0.7B in pretax noninterest expense. The note provides a reconciliation of reported GAAP figures to adjusted non-GAAP figures for key metrics like noninterest expense, net income, EPS, and return ratios.
Note B defines how reserve build (release) is calculated: by subtracting net charge-offs from the provision for credit losses for a given period.
Note C defines Pretax, pre-provision income (PTPI) as a non-GAAP measure calculated by adding back the provision for credit losses to pretax income, both at consolidated and segment levels.
Note D defines Global Liquidity Sources (GLS) as cash and high-quality, liquid, unencumbered securities, excluding Federal Reserve Discount Window or FHLB borrowing capacity.
Note E clarifies that forward-looking statements on NII outlook are based on a forecast considering business growth, ALM positioning, and market-implied interest rate movements.
Note F details the net debit valuation adjustments (DVA) on derivatives included in revenue for various periods.
Note G explains the VaR model methodology, which uses a historical simulation approach with a 99% confidence level.
(A) Estimated U.S. retail deposits based on June 30, 2023 FDIC deposit data.
(B) FDIC, 1Q24.
(C) Global Finance, April 2024.
(D) Global Finance, August 2023.
(E) Global Finance, October 2023.
(F) J.D. Power 2024 Financial Health Support Certification.
(G) Global Finance, 2024.
(H) Family Wealth Report, 2024.
(I) Global Private Banker, 2024.
(J) Euromoney, 2023.
(K) Treasury Management International, 2024.
(L) Celent, 2024.
(M) Coalition Greenwich, 2023.
(N) Global Capital, 2024.
(O) Energy Risk, 2024.
(P) Risk Awards, 2024.
(Q) Environmental Finance, 2024.
(R) FX Markets, 2024.
(S) DealCatalyst, 2024.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements, which are not guarantees of future performance and are subject to risks and uncertainties.
Words like 'anticipates,' 'expects,' 'plans,' 'believes' identify forward-looking statements.
Actual results may differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking statements.
Investors should not place undue reliance on these statements and should consider risks detailed in SEC filings, including the 2023 Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Key risks include litigation, regulatory actions, discontinuation of reference rates, geopolitical instability, interest rate and inflation impacts, credit losses, and cybersecurity incidents.
Other risks involve technology implementation (like AI), climate change impacts, political conditions, and health emergencies.
The Corporation does not undertake any obligation to update forward-looking statements.
The information is preliminary and based on data available at the time of the presentation; Bank of America has no obligation to update it.
The presentation may use non-GAAP financial measures to provide clarity on operational trends. Reconciliations are available in the quarterly earnings press release.
Key performance indicators (KPIs) are presented, which management uses to assess consolidated and segment results.
Net interest income is also viewed on a fully taxable-equivalent (FTE) basis, a non-GAAP measure, to allow for better comparison of taxable and tax-exempt sources.
Capital is allocated to business segments using a methodology that considers regulatory capital requirements and internal risk-based models.
